sen.e: In 1280 (Koan 3), Tamekane began serving crown prince Hirohito (who later became Emperor Fushimi), and the style of waka poetry in which he instructed the crown prince and his close associates came to be known as the Kyogoku school.

sen.j: 伏見天皇が践践した後は政治家としても活躍したが、持明院統側公家として皇統の迭立に関与したことから、1298年（永仁6年）佐渡国に配流となった。
sen.e: Once Emperor Fushimi ascended to the throne Tamekane also became active as a politician, but was banished to Sado province in 1298 (Einin 6) for his participation in the attempt, as an aristocratic supporter of the Jimyoin lineage, to manipulate the Imperial succession in favor of the Jimyoin line.

sen.j: 2度の流刑の背景には「徳政」の推進を通じて朝廷の権威を取り戻そうとしていた伏見天皇と鎌倉幕府の対立が激化して、為兼が天皇の身代わりとして処分されたという説もある。
sen.e: The background for why he was twice punished with exile lies in his promoting of the idea of "benevolent rule," in which he and Emperor Fushimi sought to restore true power to the imperial court and fell into an intensifying conflict with the Kamakura shogunate; one explanation has it that Tamekane served as scapegoat for the Emperor, being punished in his stead.

sen.j: 家風は実感を尊び、繊細で感覚的な表現による歌を詠み、沈滞していた鎌倉時代末期の歌壇に新風を吹き込んだ。
sen.e: In the poetic style of his family the evoking of true emotions was very highly prized, leading him to compose waka that expressed a delicate yet sensuous quality; this new style breathed life into the stagnated waka circles of late Kamakura-period Japan.
